posts.content: Hi Phil, I'm looking to get a Rivnut gun/tool, did you use a basic or a professional type?

The depth of the rear seat is 20" from front to back.

I'm using 4" foam, so you lose the depth (as the rear cushion takes this up), so the available depth is really 16".

Hope this helps ?


Hi Karl,

I bought a Sealey rivnut tool from a local shop . It's OK, and once I mastered it, it is great

http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/AK393-SEALEY- ... 5d4d5c4903

Easy to use, and perfect for me

Cheers,

Phil.
Thats great thanks, very much appreciated!

OxonPhil wrote:
The depth of the rear seat is 20" from front to back.

I'm using 4" foam, so you lose the depth (as the rear cushion takes this up), so the available depth is really 16".

Hope this helps ?


Hi Karl,

I bought a Sealey rivnut tool from a local shop . It's OK, and once I mastered it, it is great

http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/AK393-SEALEY- ... 5d4d5c4903

Easy to use, and perfect for me

Cheers,

Phil.


Thanks Phil

Just a little job tonight........it was time to fit the remote unit under my back seat for my Kyham awning lights



I have a connector under the bus where I can simply plug the lights into

This unit allows me to switch on my awning lights as I return to the bus

It also has a dimer function on it, so I can dim the lights when the kids go to bed

All tested, and glad to report that the remote unit works outside with the van doors shut


Phil.

OxonPhil wrote:
Just a little job tonight........it was time to fit the remote unit under my back seat for my Kyham awning lights



I have a connector under the bus where I can simply plug the lights into

This unit allows me to switch on my awning lights as I return to the bus

It also has a dimer function on it, so I can dim the lights when the kids go to bed

All tested, and glad to report that the remote unit works outside with the van doors shut

Thats neat!!
Phil.

Well it was a lovely hot day yesterday, so I took my bus to work

Unfortunately when I got home I could smell petrol again

So looks like just bending the float, and fitting a pressure regulator didn't work.

I tried to shove my head into the engine bay when I got home, which wasn't easy on such a hot day !!

I noticed the shaft on the right hand side carb (which is the one leaking) had a slight bit of end float in it, so will have to take the carb off to have a better look.......

No idea why the carb is leaking fuel ??

Could it be the pump ?

When I had my head in the engine bay with the engine off, I could hear fuel guzzling, so no idea what this was ???

Any ideas welcome......

Cheers,

Phil.

OxonPhil wrote:
Well it was a lovely hot day yesterday, so I took my bus to work

Unfortunately when I got home I could smell petrol again

So looks like just bending the float, and fitting a pressure regulator didn't work.

I tried to shove my head into the engine bay when I got home, which wasn't easy on such a hot day !!

I noticed the shaft on the right hand side carb (which is the one leaking) had a slight bit of end float in it, so will have to take the carb off to have a better look.......

No idea why the carb is leaking fuel ??

Could it be the pump ?

When I had my head in the engine bay with the engine off, I could hear fuel guzzling, so no idea what this was ???

Any ideas welcome......

Cheers,

Phil.

So to recap, are you running an electric fuel pump? Do you have a regulator? Leaking from the spindle joints on carbs is usually fuel pressure.

I'm running a mechanical pump, now with a Filter King pressure regulator fitted.

Do you think I have somehow damaged the carb by running without a regulator for a while ??

Anything to look out for when I remove the carb ??

Cheers,

Phil.

I managed to get on the bus this morning to have a better look at the right hand side carb.

After removal, I noticed a dark patch on the underside (by the spindle). I have seen this before, and it's dried petrol



So I decided to have a better look at the spindle, as I have seen others on here say they leak.

I took a photo of the parts in the order I removed them (so I have a chance when I put it back together ).



After looking at an exploded view, I noticed that a washer is missing......maybe this is why it had a small amount of end float ?? (I'm thinking that the nut runs out of thread before it's tight).

Looks like the seal is OK though......



But the other end the seal looks damaged



So now it's all in pieces, I thought I'd check everything......



The float position looks OK, and the only other thing I could find was a damaged o-ring on the pump.



So I'll place an order for some bits tomorrow, and hopefully this will fix it.......


A couple of questions:

1. Should the seal be flush with the end, or pushed fully home into the recess ??

2. What should I use the push the seal in so that it doesn't damage the new seal ??

3. I have read that it is worth fitting spacers between the carb and the manifold (in a hope to try and keep the carbs further away from the heat). Any comments ??


Cheers,

Phil.

Parts all arrived today, and the carb is back together

The missing washer has taken the end float up, so hopefully this is good now.

I also bought spacers, and a selection of gaskets.



I am hoping the combination of the 10mm aluminium and 6mm card gaskets will keep the heat away from the carbs..........


I'm just trying to understand the root cause of the fault (as it is a petrol issue), so that I can fix it once and for all

Hopefully the questions in the Technical section will be answered and will put my mind at ease....

Phil.

well done Phill


good luck buddy ... hope it's the fix

Mark

So my carb is all back together, this is what it looks like in place.



So the next job was to try and move it further away from the cylinder heads, as it has been suggested that the guzzling noise I heard was due to the carbs getting too hot, and the fuel in the float chambers boiling.....

Well the studs were not going to be long enough, to time to change them.







That's better

Next job was to fit the 6mm card isolators.



And the the aluminium spacer.



And finally a standard gasket.



The carb on next, and it was close, really close to the fan housing.......but it fitted




So I could have left it here, but I decided to fit a fuel cut off valve as well

So my original plan was to fit it between the tank and the fuel pump, which would be good incase of a crash, BUT my mate at work explained how a mechanical pump works, and that depending on where the pump stops, the spring inside it can either keep the pump shut, or try and squirt some extra petrol towards the carbs........so for this reason, I have decided to fit the valve between the pump and the pressure regulator

I would be interested what others think about where in the circuit I have put it, but to be honest as long as the fuel smell has gone, then I'm happy

I started by fitting inserts into the fan housing.



Trial fit.



And here it is all in place.






I was hoping to take it for a spin tonight, but work was mad today, and I got home too late

Hopefully tomorrow

Let's just hope it's worked, as otherwise I think the only other option are some really nice inlet valves for the carbs from Aircooled.net in the USA.

Phil.
These carbs have been a right royal pain in the arse

Took it out for a spin tonight, and when I got home, no glugging, or smell of fuel

Hopefully it's fixed.............

The difference the 6mm spacers make between the temperature of the manifold and the temperature of the carbs is amazing !!!

I just need to double check the air fuel mixture now, as it is rather sluggish, which may suggest too rich (I think ??).

At least it runs, and our Devon holiday is looming..........

Phil.
